details.feedback: Operator accurately repeated both cone orders and closed the sale efficiently but made no suggestive-selling attempts. While size was specified for each cone, removing valid upsizing opportunities, each cone still provided an add-on chance (double dip on the dipped cone, sprinkles on the plain cone). Offering these toppings could have increased ticket value. Coach to consistently look for and verbalize simple add-on options even when no upsize/upsell exists.

transcript:
Operator: Thank you, Derek. What can I get started for you today?
Customer: I need a small cone of vanilla dipped in chocolate.
Operator: Okay, small cone of vanilla dipped in chocolate. What else?
Customer: And a small cone of chocolate.
Operator: Chocolate ice cream?
Customer: Yes.
Operator: Okay, would that be all?
Customer: That's it.
Operator: That'll be $5.72.
Customer: Thank you.

details.feedback: Operator offered one valid upsell by suggesting a drink, which the customer declined, and correctly presented an upsizing offer for large fries that the customer accepted. This converted the only upsizing chance and demonstrated suggestive selling technique. Operator missed the additional upsell chance to recommend an extra paid dipping sauce and the chicken-basket size upgrade from 4-piece to 6-piece. Overall, good execution on the offer given, but needs to probe all identified opportunities consistently.
details.issues: Menu items JSON: 4-Piece CB Chicken (Strip) Basket shows upsell chances (Drink, Dipping Sauce) and upsize chance (Large Fries). Upselling Scenario VO-02 DrinkCB confirms valid drink offer language. Upsizing Scenario VO-04 Side confirms valid large-fries offer. Upsizing Scenario VO-13 indicates missed chance to upsize basket to 6-piece. Ambiguities: whether extra gravy counts as a separate paid item; treated it as included within basket to satisfy rule on item counts. No conflicting instructions noted.
details.items_after: 4-Piece Chicken Strip Basket (Chicken Strips, Large Fries, Gravy)
details.items_initial: 4-Piece Chicken Strip Basket (Chicken Strips, Regular Fries)

transcript:
Operator: Thank you, what can I get started for you today?
Customer: Um, can I do a four-piece chicken strip basket?
Operator: Okay, four-piece. Would that be with a drink or no drink?
Customer: Uh, no drink.
Operator: Okay, and would that be with a large fry?
Customer: Yeah, that's good.
Operator: Okay. What dip would you like with it?
Customer: Could I do gravy?
Operator: Gravy? Yeah, of course.
Customer: And an extra one.
Operator: An extra gravy?
Customer: Yeah.
Operator: Okay. What else can I get for you?
Customer: Uh, that's it.
Operator: Okay, so it'll be $10.98.
Customer: Alright, thank you.
Operator: Of course.

details.feedback: Operator missed the single upsell opportunity (2 for $5 on the small sundae) and made no topping offers. No valid upsizing chances existed because the customer specified sizes, but the operator could still have suggested a larger size as an upsell. Overall, 0/1 upsell attempts and 0/3 topping attempts were made, showing poor adherence to suggestive selling best practices. Recommend reinforcing 2-for-5 scripting and topping prompts to raise average ticket.
details.issues: Upsell opportunity referenced from Upselling Scenarios Scenario VO-01 (2for5). Item data and topping opportunities taken from Menu JSON entries: 'Sundae [Size: Small]' (2for5, toppings), 'Cone [Sizes]' (sprinkles), 'Dipped Cone [Sizes]' (double dip). Upsizing ruled out via Upsizing Scenario Null-02 (specific sizes requested). Ambiguity: 'kid's twist cone' mapped to small twist cone; treated as size specified to remove upsize chance. Customer-requested sprinkles not counted as successful add-on because operator did not initiate offer.

transcript:
Operator: What can I get for you?
Customer: Hey, can I get a small strawberry sundae?
Operator: Of course. What else can I get for you, ma'am?
Customer: A kid's twist cone with sprinkles.
Customer: Can I get a small chocolate dipped cone, please?
Operator: Yes, ma'am.
Customer: That's it.
Operator: Would you like to round up for our Note in the Pocket Kids charity?
Customer: Sure.
Operator: I do appreciate it. It's going to bring you to $10 even, ma'am. Have a great day.
Customer: Thank you.

details.feedback: Operator confirmed the requested small size, which meant no valid upsize opportunity per Scenario Null-02. They did not suggest adding extra mix-ins to the Blizzard, missing the single additional-topping chance. No items in the order qualified for meal or combo upsells. Interaction was courteous but lacked any suggestive selling effort.

transcript:
Operator: Thank you for choosing DQ. What can I get for you today?
Customer: Hang on.
Operator: Take your time.
Customer: I would like a small blizzard. Is it gone already? The Reese's caramel one?
Operator: Yes, ma'am. We no longer carry that. I do apologize.
Customer: All right, then I'll have a turtle pecan cluster blizzard.
Operator: Small size?
Customer: Small, yes.
Operator: All right, can I get you anything else?
Customer: I mean, the Reese's peanut butter cup.
Customer: No, that's it. Thank you.
Operator: Okay, so we want the peanut butter cup and we want the turtle pecan?
Customer: I want the pecan.
Operator: All right, it's going to be $5.40. Thank you very much.

details.feedback: The operator was polite and confirmed the order accurately but missed the single suggestive-selling chance: offering a Double Dip add-on for the dipped cone. No valid upsell or upsize chances existed because the customer specified a medium size and cones are not tied to combo promotions. In future, proactively offer Double Dip or sprinkles on cone orders to increase average check.

No conflicting instructions or ambiguities encountered.

transcript:
Operator: Thank you for the DT Coffee, what can I get for you today?
Customer: Can I have a medium dip cone?
Operator: No problem at all. What else can I get for you, ma'am?
Customer: That'll be all.
Operator: Would you like to round up for our note in the pocket kids charity?
Customer: No, just hot.
Operator: I definitely appreciate it. The same is going to be $4.21. Have a great day.

details.feedback: Operator handled basic order accurately but missed all suggestive-selling chances. No upsell applicable, yet there was a valid upsizing opportunity to offer a box of six Dilly Bars (Scenario VO-11) and a valid add-on for the dipped cone (double dip). Offering either would have boosted ticket average and met Dairy Queen’s sales protocol. Recommend proactively suggesting the box-of-six when any single Dilly Bar is ordered and mentioning double-dip or sprinkles for cones. Also remember to ask about making unstated-size items large when appropriate.
details.issues: Menu-item JSON: Dilly Bar (upsizing to box of 6) and Dipped Cone (add-on double dip). Upsizing scenarios table VO-11 confirms valid offer for Dilly Bar. Add-on derived from menu JSON field “Add on Chance: Double Dip” for Dipped Cone. No upsell scenarios matched items, so upsell chances = 0. Ambiguities: customer specified medium cone, removing upsizing chance; bottled water has no size. All counts follow hard rules.

transcript:
Operator: Thank you for choosing Dairy Queen. What can I get started for you today?
Customer: Well, I have a question about non-dairy. Do you have anything non-dairy besides the Dilly Bar?
Operator: Other than the Dilly Bar, then no, I don't think we do.
Customer: Okay, we'll have one of those, and then we'll have a medium dip cone and a bottle of water.
Operator: And a bottle of water. Okay. What else can I get for you?
Customer: That's it for it.
Operator: Okay, well, I'll have that right out.

Customer: Take your time.

Operator: That'll be $5.40 at the window. Would you like to round up for non-profit charities?
Customer: No, thank you.

details.feedback: Operator accurately recorded the customer’s order but did not attempt any suggestive selling. While no upsell or upsize chances existed because the item was already a large Blizzard, there was one valid opportunity to add extra mix-ins (extra Oreo pieces) which was not offered. Encourage proactively offering additional toppings for Blizzards in future interactions to increase check averages.

transcript: Operator: Order 73, large mint Oreo. All right, got the third.

details.feedback: Operator confirmed items clearly but missed suggestive-selling opportunities. A 2 for 5 upsell was available on the small strawberry sundae but was not offered. When size on the sundae was unspecified, the operator asked What size is that? instead of offering the largest size, counting as an invalid upsizing offer and losing the chance to increase check size. No attempt was made to add toppings such as sprinkles, nuts or whipped cream to either dessert. To improve, use approved phrasing like Would you like that large today? and highlight deals such as 2 for 5, and always offer dessert add-ons.
details.issues: Upselling reference: Upselling Scenarios VO-01 (2for5) and NO-01 (no offer). Upsizing reference: Upsizing Scenarios IO-02 (invalid offer when asking size). Additional topping chances taken from Menu Items JSON entries for Cone and Sundae. Ambiguities: Kids cone size not listed in menu JSON; treated as size-specified so no upsizing chance. Determined that clarifying size counts as an invalid upsizing offer rather than valid.

transcript:
Operator: One second please, I'm sorry.
Customer: You're fine.
Operator: Welcome to Dairy Queen, don't worry about that.
Customer: You're good. Can I just get a kid's chocolate cone?
Operator: A kid's chocolate cone?
Customer: Yes, please.
Operator: Oh, can I get something else now?
Customer: And then a strawberry sundae.
Operator: What size is that, that strawberry sundae?
Customer: A small one, please.
Operator: A small strawberry sundae, kid's chocolate cone? Alright, can I get something else now?
Customer: That'll be it, thank you.
Operator: Alright, would you like to round up for a note in the pocket, kid's charity?
Customer: No, thank you.
Operator: Alright, let's see, 15, that was right there, ma'am.
Customer: Thank you.
Operator: You're very welcome.

details.feedback: Operator offered friendly service and confirmed details but provided no suggestive-selling language. When the Kids Meal was ordered there was a valid Scenario VO-05 opportunity to upsell the side from fries to cheese curds/onion rings; the customer ended up requesting this upgrade on their own, showing the chance was missed. No upsell or drink-size offers were attempted, so conversion remained zero. Recommend proactively offering side upgrades and other valid upsizing phrases to boost sales.

No upsell chances according to Menu JSON for Kids Meal. Ambiguity: transcript includes both drink and vanilla cup treat even though Kids Meal JSON lists only three inclusions; followed table and counted three items, treating vanilla cup as customer-specific but not counted toward item total.

transcript:
Operator: It's a wonderful day at Dairy Queen, what can I get for you today?
Customer: Um, let's see, can I do, huh, the kid's two-piece chicken strip?
Operator: Okay, the kid's two-piece chicken strip?
Customer: Uh-huh.
Operator: And it comes with what kind of drink?
Customer: Um, a small Sprite.
Operator: Alright, and any dipping sauce for you?
Customer: Barbecue sauce.
Operator: Alright, did you want a cup, cone, or a dilly bar for the treat for that?
Customer: I'll do a cup.
Operator: Okay, cup of vanilla?
Customer: Yes.
Operator: Alright, what else for you?
Customer: Can I actually take the fries off of that and just get cheese curds upgraded?
Operator: Yeah. Did you want marinara, blue cheese, or ranch?
Customer: Oh, no thank you.
Operator: Okay, anything else?
Customer: That's all.
Operator: That's going to be $9.18. Did you want to round up to $10 for a note in the pocket today?
Customer: Sure.
Operator: We do appreciate that very much. We'll see you at the window for $10 even.
Customer: Thank you.
Operator: Thank you.

details.feedback: Operator was courteous but missed all suggestive selling opportunities. While the order contained no burger or combo items for meal upsells and every item already had a stated size (so no upsize chance), both Blizzards carried clear additional-topping opportunities such as extra Oreo pieces or cake mix-ins. The agent made no attempt to offer these. No valid upsell or upsize offers were given, resulting in zero conversions.
details.issues: Referenced Menu JSON: Cheese Curds entry (Large size specified, upsell 0, upsize 0), Blizzard entry (Add on Chance: Primary topping, Upsizing Chance only if size unspecified). Upsell Scenario table confirms upsell chances apply mainly to burgers, hotdogs, etc., none present. Upsizing Scenario table VO-06 requires size unspecified, which it was not. Additional topping logic from menu JSON used for chances. Ambiguity: whether two marinara cups are chargeable; treated as free condiment so excluded from item count as per guideline not to list non-chargeable condiments.

transcript:
Operator: It's a wonderful day at Dairy Queen, how can I help you?
Customer: Can I get a large curd, two marinara?
Operator: Okay.
Customer: A medium confetti cake.
Operator: Okay.
Customer: A medium Oreo.
Operator: Alright, so a medium confetti cake, medium Oreo, and then a large cheese curd?
Customer: Yeah, we got the two marinara.
Operator: Alright, that's it.
Customer: Alright, you can pull forward, okay?
Operator: Appreciate it.
Customer: You're welcome.

details.feedback: Operator was friendly and acknowledged donation but missed the sole upselling opportunity: pairing the drink with another 2-for-$5 item. A brief offer such as suggesting a small sundae, pretzel, or chili dog would have met suggestive-selling standards. No upsize chance existed because guest already chose the largest size. Continue watching for promo-based add-ons even on simple beverage orders.

details.feedback: Operator accurately captured the guest’s order but missed every suggestive-selling cue. A three-piece chicken strips order carries automatic chances to add fries or a small sundae/blizzard or convert to a basket; none were offered. The Sprite was ordered without a size, presenting a valid upsizing chance to a large drink, yet the operator merely confirmed the drink. No compliant VO-style phrasing such as Would you like to add fries with that? or Would you like your drink large today? was used. Zero offers means zero conversions and lost revenue potential.
details.issues: Table references: Menu Items JSON – 3-Piece Chicken Strips (upselling chance Drink, Fries, Sundae/Blizzard) and Drink [Sizes: Small, Medium, Large] (upsizing chance Large Drink). Difficulties: Transcript line I hope they were Sunday was unclear; interpreted as operator mishearing sundae, guest declined, so no sundae added. Ranch treated as complimentary sauce, not a priced item. Customer requested drink themselves, so drink upsell opportunity considered satisfied; remaining upsell chances calculated for fries and sundae only.

transcript:
Operator: It's a wonderful day at Dairy Queen, how can I help you?
Customer: Can I get your three-piece chicken strip?
Operator: You have a three-piece chicken strip?
Customer: Yes, please.
Operator: Alright.
Customer: And can I do ranch, please, with a Sprite?
Operator: No problem. I hope they were Sunday.
Customer: Honestly, I really don't want it. I don't want it.
Operator: No problem. Anything else for today?
Customer: No, that's it.
Operator: $7.58 at the window.
Customer: Thank you.

details.feedback: Operator accurately repeated the customer’s order and closed efficiently, but missed revenue-building chances. A dipped cone with no size specified presented a valid upsizing opportunity (Scenario VO-09 for cones); however, the operator defaulted to medium instead of asking if the guest wanted it large, resulting in a missed upsizing offer. Both cones also allow add-on toppings (sprinkles for vanilla, double dip for dipped cone), yet no suggestive topping offers were made. No upsell chances were relevant, so none were required. Strength: clear order confirmation. Improvement: when size is not given, explicitly offer the large size; routinely suggest applicable cone add-ons.

details.feedback: Operator took the order accurately but missed all suggestive selling opportunities. transcript:
Operator: How can I help you?
Customer: I'd like a medium cone of vanilla dipped in chocolate, is that all?
Operator: Alright, no problem. You total will be $4.21. It is to round up a bit on the pocket today.
Operator: Alright, you can pull forward ma'am.
Customer: I am.

details.feedback: Operator took the order accurately but missed all suggestive-selling chances. Each Diet Coke qualified for a 2-for-$5 upsell, and none were offered. Because drink sizes were not specified, three valid offers to upsize to large drinks should have been made. The mini Blizzard had one chance for an extra-topping add-on (extra M&Ms) that was also skipped. No invalid phrasing was used, but the absence of offers means the call fell short of Dairy Queen’s selling standards. Focus on: 1) When a standalone drink is ordered, always present the 2-for-$5 add-on per VO-01. 2) Whenever size is not stated for drink, fries, or treat, proactively ask if they’d like it large using the approved language (e.g., “Would you like that large today?”). 3) Offer extra toppings on every Blizzard or treat. Consistent use of these techniques will lift check averages and meet corporate policy.
details.issues: Upselling reference: VO-01 table – any size drink qualifies for 2for5. Upsizing reference: VO-02 table – drinks with no size have chance to upsize. Additional topping reference: Menu JSON – Blizzard add-on chance: Primary topping/ingredient. Item details confirmed in Menu JSON for Drink and Blizzard. Difficulties: Customer didn’t specify drink size (treated as unsized per rules). Blizzard size was explicitly mini, so no upsize chance. No conflict noted.

details.feedback: Operator confirmed the order clearly and remained courteous but did not attempt any suggestive selling. A Blizzard always allows an add-on chance such as extra mix-ins; the agent missed this by waiting for the guest to request it. Size was specified so no upsize chance existed, and Blizzards have no combo upsell path. Recommend proactively offering extra toppings or a larger size when appropriate to boost sales and meet Dairy Queen suggestive selling standards.
